quiz.title: Grade 12 Physics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 10: Motors, Generators & Energy Conversion
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: As an electric motor spins, it also acts like a generator, creating a voltage that opposes the input voltage. This is called:
questions.explanation: Back EMF (counter-electromotive force) is induced as the motor's armature coils rotate through the magnetic field. By Lenz's Law, it opposes the applied voltage, limiting current and preventing infinite acceleration.

questions.question: If a motor is physically prevented from turning while the power is on (stalled), what happens to the current?
options: It increases significantly, potentially burning out the motor.
It becomes AC instead of DC.
questions.explanation: With no rotation, no back EMF is generated. The full source voltage appears across the coil resistance, causing dangerously high current $I = V/R$, which can overheat and damage the motor.

questions.question: In a DC motor, the "split-ring commutator" is essential because it:
options: Reverses the current every half-cycle to maintain continuous rotation in one direction.
Protects the user from electric shock.
questions.explanation: The commutator reverses current direction in the armature coil each half-rotation, ensuring the magnetic torque always acts in the same rotational direction rather than causing oscillation.

questions.question: The torque produced by a motor is maximum when the plane of the coil is:
questions.explanation: Maximum torque occurs when the coil sides are perpendicular to the magnetic field lines, which happens when the coil plane is parallel to the field. At this orientation, $\tau = NIAB$ (for N turns).

questions.question: Which of the following is an application of electromagnetic energy conversion?
questions.explanation: All involve conversion between mechanical and electrical energy via electromagnetic induction: regenerative braking (kinetic → electrical), hydroelectric (gravitational → electrical), wind turbines (wind → electrical).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand the principles of motors and generators, including back EMF, commutation, torque optimization, and real-world energy conversion applications.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid grasp of motor/generator fundamentals. Review the relationship between back EMF and motor speed, and how commutators enable continuous DC motor rotation.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) The concept of back EMF and its effect on motor current, 2) The purpose of the split-ring commutator, 3) Conditions for maximum torque, 4) Real-world applications of electromagnetic energy conversion.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review how motors use magnetic forces to produce rotation, how generators use motion to produce electricity, and the relationship between these two complementary devices.
